{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3417440,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-22T19:24:27.865Z","cooked":"

Inspired by Rev’s new bumper mounting system, Here’s a quick sketch [onshape link] for a system to mount bumpers to an SDS Mk4i swerve module:

  • The blue part is 1/4" thick aluminum,
  • the grey part is 1/8" aluminum sheet metal which rivets/screws into the bumper with countersunk holes.
  • The orange fasteners are these 1/4-20 thumb screws which Celt-X has been using to attach bumpers since 2018.
  • The eyebolt is for clipping on lifting handles with a carabiner.
  • The blue plate can be modified to mount directly to the frame 2x1s (replacing the Mk4i L plate) if we choose to mount the module under the frame.

If approved, we might try making this in 2025, but I’d love to get any feedback offered before then.

image (55)910×718 253 KB

image (54)932×697 198 KB

2023/24 Product Releases & Updates","clicks":70},{"url":"https://cad.onshape.com/documents/cf710b6445cea408af4740e4/w/72a46260e22075b1fab757a8/e/af39479d3d027c3be854568c?renderMode=0&uiState=66c78f1fc801d7447071a7ce","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Onshape","clicks":19},{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/98704A620/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":13},{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/93372A429/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":4},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-bumper-issues-has-your-team-had/505301/46","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"What Bumper issues has your team had?","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/celt-x-5406-2025-build-thread-open-alliance/479816/26","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Celt-X 5406 | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules/470146/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3417442,"name":"Tim Winters","username":"ArchdukeTim","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-22T19:33:44.216Z","cooked":"

Seems like a lot of leverage will be applied to those bolts during forceful hits. How necessary is it to raise the mounting points up from the top plate?

It also seems like you also have the outermost bolts terminating where frame tubing would be attached to the module. That either requires a nut to be on the inside of the tube, countersunk head, or a bolt that goes all the way through the tube to the bottom.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-08-22T19:33:44.216Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":362,"readers_count":361,"score":77.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470146,"topic_slug":"bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules/470146/2","custom_user_title":"78 AIR Strike Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417443,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-22T19:35:47.760Z","cooked":"
ArchdukeTim:

Seems like a lot of leverage will be applied to those bolts during forceful hits. How necessary is it to raise the mounting points up from the top plate?

It’s not mandatory, but we have found in past that it’s easier to get the mounting bolts on if they’re close to the top of the bumper. Much lower and it’s hard to get your fingers in. I take your point about the leverage though.

ArchdukeTim:

It also seems like you also have the outermost bolts terminating where frame tubing would be attached to the module. That either requires a nut to be on the inside of the tube,

The SDS top plates include threaded holes there, so no nuts are required.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-08-22T19:35:47.760Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":375,"readers_count":374,"score":105.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470146,"topic_slug":"bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules/470146/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417444,"name":"Ian Saam","username":"Enjsnake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/enjsnake/{size}/201559_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-22T19:36:13.963Z","cooked":"

We’ve been doing something similar these past two years, and feel pretty good about what we came up with. This is what we used in 2023:

IMG_35394032×3024 2.75 MB
, just sitting on top of a 3d print we put around the edge of the module. Unlike your design, we didn’t bend the plates and had the screws holding the bracket onto the wood back out repeatedly. This year, we got a couple bent plates from fabworks that only attached the the very corner bolt of the module(still on a slight 0.25 plate riser):
IMG_5063575×775 158 KB

Aside from using a 10/32 bolt originally and completely destroying all four of them in about 10 minutes, once changing them to 1/4-20 we’ve had 0 issues all season(including some pretty violent collisions), and likely will continue to use something similar in following seasons.

How well do these brackets obey the 1-in hard parts rule in bumpers? I thought that the one inch applied both into and out of the frame, but would love to be wrong

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-08-22T23:33:20.707Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":257,"readers_count":256,"score":61.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470146,"topic_slug":"bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules/470146/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417475,"name":"Garrison","username":"Garrison","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/garrison/{size}/7824_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-22T23:37:55.120Z","cooked":"

The 1-inch hard part rule starts at the inner face (close to robot) of the bumper wood and extends outward towards the noodles. We selected bolts + nuts to attach the brackets to the wood that were short enough to not extend more than 1 inch out.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-08-22T23:37:55.120Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":80.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470146,"topic_slug":"bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules","display_username":"Garrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28019,"username":"s-neff","name":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23755,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/bumper-and-lifting-eye-mount-design-for-mk4i-n-swerve-modules/470146/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417493,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T02:36:06.164Z","cooked":"

What @Garrison said. The 1" hard part limit only applies outward. Anything inboard of the frame perimeter is fair game, as it doesn’t interfere with the noodle squish.
